articles.author: MARK SHERMAN
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — The Supreme Court on Thursday unanimously preserved access to a medication that was used in nearly two-thirds of all abortions in the U.S.
articles.title: Unanimous Supreme Court preserves access to widely used abortion medication

articles.author: NICOLE WINFIELD, PAOLO SANTALUCIA and COLLEEN LONG
articles.description: BORGO EGNAZIA, Italy (AP) — A Group of Seven summit opened Thursday with agreement reached on a U.S. proposal to back a $50 billion loan to Ukraine using frozen Russian assets as collateral, giving Kyiv a strong show of support even as Europe's political chessboard shifts to the right.
articles.title: G7 summit opens with deal to use Russian assets for Ukraine as Italy flexes its right-wing muscles

articles.author: TOM KRISHER and DAVID HAMILTON
articles.description: DETROIT (AP) — Tesla shareholders voted Thursday to restore CEO Elon Musk's record $44.9 billion pay package that was thrown out by a Delaware judge earlier this year, sending a strong vote of confidence in his leadership of the electric vehicle maker.
articles.title: Elon Musk wins back his $44.9 billion Tesla pay package in shareholder vote

articles.author: LISA MASCARO
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — Donald Trump made a triumphant return to Capitol Hill on Thursday, his first with lawmakers since the Jan.6, 2021 attacks, embraced by energized House and Senate Republicans who find themselves reinvigorated by his bid to retake the White House.
articles.title: Cheers, cake and a fist-bump from GOP as Trump returns to Capitol Hill in a first since Jan. 6 riot

articles.author: JACQUES BILLEAUD
articles.description: PHOENIX (AP) — Phoenix police discriminate against Black, Hispanic and Native American people, unlawfully detain homeless people and use excessive force, including unjustified deadly force, according to a sweeping federal civil rights investigation of law enforcement in the nation's fifth-largest city.
articles.title: Phoenix police have pattern of violating civil rights and using excessive force, Justice Dept. says

articles.author: COLLEEN LONG
articles.description: FASANO, Italy (AP) — President Joe Biden said Thursday that he will not use his presidential powers to lessen the eventual sentence that his son Hunter will receive for his federal felony conviction on gun crimes.
articles.title: President Biden says he won't offer commutation to his son Hunter after gun sentence

articles.author: SEUNG MIN KIM and STEPHEN GROVES
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — President Joe Biden will host a White House event next week celebrating an Obama-era directive that offered deportation protections for young undocumented immigrants, as his own administration prepares potential new benefits for others without legal status but with long-standing ties in the United States.
articles.title: White House preps 'dreamers' celebration while President Biden eyes new benefits for immigrants

articles.author: MARY CLARE JALONICK
articles.description: Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Dick Durbin says his committee has uncovered at least three additional trips given to Justice Clarence Thomas by GOP megadonor Harlan Crow as part of the panel’s ethics investigation into the Supreme Court.
articles.title: Justice Clarence Thomas took more trips paid for by donor Harlan Crow, Senate panel reveals

articles.author: FREIDA FRISARO, TERRY SPENCER and DANIEL KOZIN
articles.description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) — A tropical disturbance that brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida delayed flights at two of the state's largest airports and left vehicles waterlogged and stalled in some of the region's lowest-lying streets.
articles.title: Tropical rainstorms in South Florida lead to flight delays and streets jammed with stalled cars

articles.author: GENE JOHNSON
articles.description: SEATTLE (AP) — The United States granted the Makah Indian Tribe in Washington state a long-sought waiver Thursday that helps clear the way for its first sanctioned whale hunts since 1999 and sets the stage for renewed clashes with animal rights activists.
articles.title: Washington's Makah Tribe could once again harpoon whales as US waives conservation law
